image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Minnesota; born in Doylestown, Bucks County, Pa., April 1, 1851; attended the public and normal schools; moved to Minnesota in 1872 and settled in what is now known as Buckman; engaged in agricultural pursuits and in the lumber business; appointed justice of the peace in 1873; member of the State house of representatives 1881-1883; served in the State senate 1887-1891 and 1899-1903; elected as a Republican to the Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Congresses (March 4, 1903-March 3, 1907); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1906; deputy United States marshal 1912-1917; resumed the lumber business in Little Falls, Morrison County, Minn.; died in Battle Creek, Mich., March 1, 1917; interment in Oakland Cemetery, Little Falls, Minn.

researchRecord.name: In the Charles A. Lindbergh and Family Papers, 1808-1985, 8.25 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Clarence B. Buckman. An inventory is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1890-1976, 26 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Clarence Bennett Buckman consist of photocopies of a Buckman family genealogy, 1680s-1976; obituaries and tributes to Clarence Buckman (1917) from Minnesota newspapers; and miscellany (1890s-1973) including data on the 1902 Minnesota elections, a 1904 speech to the U.S. House of Representatives by George W. Norris (Nebraska), Minnesota State Auditor S. G. Iverson (1906), the 1893 opening of the Buckman Hotel in Little Falls (1973), and the pharmaceutical and forestry careers of Clarence Buckman's son, Mark (undated and 1937). The original papers were loaned for copying by Clarence B. Buckman II, St. Paul.
